msDesc.head: Collection of medical, cosmetic, culinary and household recipes

summary.seg: This manuscript contains a large collection of medical recipes, including ones for poultices, powders, decoctions, oils, waters, syrups, balms, plasters, ointments, and pills, interspersed by cosmetic and household recipes. Among the latter are recipes for conserving nuts and fruits, for making spiced wine ('Hippocras'), and for making ink and pigments.

The headers of the medical recipes often feature words that have been written in Greek letters. At first, Greek letters were routinely used in rubrics in this manuscript, including medical terms for diseases and treatments, and for innocuous culinary recipes such as making white or red jelly or how to preserve walnuts. However, in later sections they appear to have been especially applied to taboo words: e.g. Winchester geese (for venereal disease, f. 48v), swelling in the testicles and swelling of the yard (i.e. in the penis, f. 68r), and neather partes (f. 71r).

While the manuscript has been dated to the 15th century by the Catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, 5 vols (Cambridge, 1856-1867) and Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), The Index of Middle English Prose, 17 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009), references to sources such as An antidotarie chyrurgicall containing great varietie and choice of all sorts of medicines that commonly fal into the chyrurgions use (London: Orwin, 1589) by the anatomist and surgeon John Banister (1533-1610) (see ff. 54v-55r) and A right profitable booke for all disseases Called The pathway to health (London: White, 1587) by the physician Peter Levens (fl. 1587) (see ff. 23r-24r) indicate that the manuscript was produced at the end of the sixteenth century with possible additions from the beginning of the seventeenth century. This much later date is also suggested by the contents of the recipes. Among these is a previously unnoticed selection of medical recipes (see ff. 67r-68r) that are attributed to King Henry VIII (r. 1509–1547) and his Royal physicians in London, British Library, Sloane MS 1047 (c. 1540-c. 1545).

Although the manuscript's compilers and intended users are unknown, the earliest owner of the manuscript appears to have been a 'John Troutbeck' who has signed his name in a 17th-century hand on f. 55v. This may have been John Troutbeck (bap. 1612, d. 1683)Troutbeck, John (bap. 1612, d. 1683), a physician and chemist, who probably fought for Parliament during the civil wars, serving as a surgeon in Yorkshire (on Troutbeck's life, see Peter Elmer, 'Troutbeck, John (bap. 1612, d. 1684)', in the Oxford Dictionary of National Bibliography (2016) [accessed 1 February 2023]). A clue for this identification may be a draft letter by the same John Troutbeck who has signed his name addressing a 'Captain John Daniell'.

Moreover, it is possible that John Troubeck's father, Edmund Troutbeck (d. 1659) of Hope Hall, Bramham, Yorkshire, owned or accessed the manuscript as well. Edmund, who was known as a surgeon and physician in his lifetime, may have been responsible for signing various recipes in the manuscript with his initials 'E.T.', in order to indicate that he had used them: for example on f. 8r, tried ET and good ET.

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

msItem.title: Collection of medical, cosmetic, and culinary recipes
msItem.note: The collection begins with a recipe for a powder called Alexipharmacon.
The collection mainly included medical recipes but there are also a few culinary recipes for conserving nuts and fruits and making spiced wine called Hippocras (f. 19r).
The collection contains one recipe with a reference to an unidentified physician: aprovide G.L. (f. 22v).

msItem.title: Recipes extraced out of A right profitable booke for all disseases Called The pathway to health (London: White, 1587)
msItem.author: Peter Levens (fl. 1587)
msItem.rubric: 23r Out of the Pathe waye to healthe

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection contains various references to physicians or other medical practitioners: Mr Andrews black salve (f. 26r) and Mr Andrew (f. 26v) [not identified]; Mr Frese his plaster (f. 27r) and Mr freces his plaster (f. 28v) [possibly James Frise/Friis, royal physician to Edward IV]; Mistris Comes [? Gomez] hirr sweete water (f. 31v) [not identified]; Docter Steavnes [sic: Stevens] water (f. 31v) [not identified but this recipe occurs in various sixteenth- and seventeenth-century medical manuscripts and printed books].

msItem.title: Syrups and waters for digesting phlegm
msItem.rubric: 34r Tabula Secunda: Off Syrupes and Waters appropriat vnto euerye member to digeste flegme
msItem.note: ff. 34r-37v have been copied by the same hand, and the items contained in them appear to belong together.

msItem.title: Syrups and waters for digesting choleric
msItem.rubric: 35r Syrrupes and Waters appropriate vnto euery member to digeste Choler
msItem.note: ff. 34r-37v have been copied by the same hand, and the items contained in them appear to belong together.

msItem.title: Liquids for purging humours
msItem.rubric: 36r Off medicines purging in Liquide forme euerye eche humoure
msItem.note: ff. 34r-37v have been copied by the same hand, and the items contained in them appear to belong together.

msItem.title: Pills for purging humours
msItem.rubric: 36r Off purging medicines of solide substaunce, and made into forme of Pilles
msItem.note: ff. 34r-37v have been copied by the same hand, and the items contained in them appear to belong together.

msItem.title: Collection of seven medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection includes a references to a physician: John Woodes method in curinge ould ulcers (f. 38r) [not identified].

msItem.title: Formulary for medical prescriptions
msItem.rubric: 39r Dyuerse formes of prescribinge meanes of remedies
msItem.note: Collection of medical recipes copied by a single hand, including pills ('tabullas' or 'morsellos') and dietary instructions.

msItem.title: Dietary
msItem.rubric: 43v Off such as engender good and evill Juice and proruith good and evill digestive
msItem.incipit: 43v Theise meates followinge are easie of digestive and make good Juice
msItem.explicit: 46v meates of evill digestione, sheep, in the day, and after supper, for, the space, of two howers, Travill of mynde, speaciallye after dynner as musinge readinge wryhtinge and such like

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection includes Oyle of Exeter and a references to a physicians: John Brinser agaynst the same (f. 51r) [not identified].

msItem.title: Four recipes extracted from An antidotarie chyrurgicall containing great varietie and choice of all sorts of medicines that commonly fal into the chyrurgions use (London: Orwin, 1589)
msItem.author: John Banister
msItem.note: With three additional recipes for poultices and powders in a differen hand that do not originate from Banister's work.

msItem.title: Draft letters and pen trails
msItem.note: Draft letters addressed to John Daniell Captain and To his very loving son [?George] Elli[s] in Edenbourow
Added by a 17th-century owner, probably John Troutbeck, who has signed his name three times on the page.

msItem.title: Notes based on a work on chirurgy by Hieronymus Brunschwig (c. 1450-c. 1512)
msItem.author: Hieronymus Brunschwig
msItem.rubric: 56r Principale notes gathered in redinge ouer Jherome of Brunswike
msItem.incipit: 56r Imprimis never attempte to consolidate ane wounde befor all tofalles or symptomates be removede
msItem.explicit: 56r ffor a splent of a horse legg [...] Take euphorbium and cantharides

msItem.title: List of medical equipment required for treating penetration and gunshot wounds, contusions, and carrying out amputations
msItem.rubric: 57r The names of suche thinges as oughte to be had in redines abought curinge, woundes made by sharpe weapones, blunte called contuced woundes, and for woundes made with gunne shote yea and for the takinge of deplorate members
msItem.incipit: 57r flaxe: Imprimis flax for smale woundes to applie
msItem.explicit: 57v lynte to applye uppon reciptes in woundes

msItem.title: Medical treatment for ruptures
msItem.incipit: 58v In the firste three dayse or vntill the wounde be digested or yeldethe matter, Take of our Emplastrum Digestivum
msItem.explicit: 59r warme weather greatlye profiteth to the digestione of the wound and for mittigatinge of sornes and payne and inflammationes etcaetera Aphoris lib 5 Apho. 22

msItem.title: Table with dietary advice and treatments for a rupture
msItem.incipit: 60r Diete: Mutton of a yeare olde
msItem.explicit: 60v Oft of the Cerote: Spreade it vppon leather, and tye it toe with a trusse chaunginge yt euerye weeke, Thuse procede every weecke, vntill fortie dayes be passsede, countinge the dayes afore sayde

msItem.title: Medical recipe for rupture
msItem.author: Richard Burrell
msItem.incipit: 61r ffirst laye the opartye [sic] on his backe in his bedd , and reduce his rupture
msItem.explicit: 61v he muste lye vppon his backe xxj or thirtye dayes for this meate ingendereth a humoure moste agreable to the panicles and partlye of his owne substaunce
msItem.note: Richard Burrell has not been identified.

note.p: The collection contains references to various physicians or other medical practitioners: Christopher Grayes his plaster (f. 62r) [not identified]; Mr Nicholas plaster (f. 62r) and Nicholas sweete oyntmente for mal morb. (f. 64v [not identified] Jo. Bru. (f. 66r) [not identified].

The collection contains a cataplasm that is said to have been devised for King Henry VIII: A Cataplasme or Pultas devised for the kinges Maiestie to mitigate payne and agaynste inflamationes and to resolue hardnes (f. 67r). The very same recipe occurs in London, British Library, Sloane MS 1047, ff. 89v-90r, where it is attributed to Henry VIII himself, who is said to have devised it at Hampton Court. The untitled cataplasm on ff. 67r-67v also features in Sloane MS 1047, ff. 90r-90v (with a slight variation at the end), where it is said to have been devised by Henry VIII at St James's Palace. Another untitled cataplasm on ff. 67v-68r can be found in Sloane MS 1047, f. 91r, where it is said to have been devised by William Butts (c. 1486–1545), one of Henry VIII's physicians.

msItem.title: Treatments for burning heat and putrefaction
msItem.rubric: 73r Receiptes to allaye the Burninge and raginge heate of choler in simple distemperat[um] and to resiste contagis or putrifaction in feuers, pestelente and other putrefacte feuers and affectes or deseases
msItem.incipit: 73r In vehemente thirst cominge of a vehemente distemper minister good springe water beinge firste boyled with a peece of leavened breade in it
msItem.explicit: 74r Recipe: honye a pynte, water a pynte, boyle them easelie on the fyer together vntill it be cleane from waxe and such other, and then boyle it to the highte of honye or more be it / yf the partie delighte

msItem.title: Names and explanations of diseases
msItem.textLang: Latin medical terms with explanations in English
msItem.incipit: 76r Allopice is the falling of heare, it is also a manner of leperye viz heate in the brewes and bearde
msItem.explicit: 76v Dialetike passione is when one pisseth offten and of greate quantitie and as sone as he hath droncke he pisseth incontinente, and that cometh of heate of the raynes etcaetera

msItem.title: Fragment of a diagnostic text
msItem.incipit: 77r principalle memberes, or other interioure partes (for if it be fluxible it will redilie yelde vnto medicine the other the contrarie)
msItem.explicit: 77r 24: and whether he hath vsed much purginge or bledinge or bothe or little or none
msItem.note: A checklist with points for a physician to consider when examining patients: it begins imperfectly mid-sentence in point 17 and continues until point 24.

msItem.title: A recipe
msItem.note: A list of ingredients for a recipe with an unspecified purpose; it appears to have been added by a later (17th-century) hand.

msItem.title: Household recipes for washing
msItem.rubric: 80r An excellente receipte to make wash[ing ther]with
msItem.note: Three recipes for washing.

msItem.title: Recipes for making ink and pigments
msItem.note: The recipes are for Redd Incke the true Coppye, Blacke Incke a good Coppie, A verye good grene (and another recipe for the same), An Emeraulde greene, and To make colour lyke gould.

msItem.title: Treatment to cure gunshot wounds
msItem.rubric: 81r A Shorte methode or to cure woundes made with gunshote
msItem.incipit: 81r Understande all woundes made with gunshott are contuside and are to be cured as contuside wowndes
msItem.explicit: 83v after gyue a draught of aqua vite and dryncke mixede or such other to comforte the stomake agayne
msItem.note: ff. 81r-85v have been copied by the same hand.

msItem.title: Treatment to cure contused wounds not caused by gunshot
msItem.rubric: 83v The Cure of other woundes contusid or nate made with guneshote
msItem.incipit: 83v Understaunde yt that smale woundes made with cuttes and no substaunce joyne the lippes of the wounde together the bloude beinge staunchede
msItem.explicit: 85r In steade of plantayne water yow maye take of the decoction of the mouthe water or such other
msItem.note: ff. 81r-85v have been copied by the same hand.

msItem.title: Treatment for pulled sinews
msItem.rubric: 85vThe Euer of wrestinges of sinewes or joyntes in anye parte of the bodye, especially in the legges
msItem.incipit: 85v ffor the same cure presentlye applye this plaster: Recipe newe hogges dounge [ounce] iij, the yolkes and whites of eges in number iij, good viniger [ounce] ij , the fyne flower of barlye and beanes ana [ounce] ij, j Bole [dram] ij to alter the colloure mixe altogether and applye it warme
msItem.explicit: 85v Recipe: the meales of fenogrecke, lynsede, and murtilles ana quantum satis Cromes of rye bread boyle them in water vntill it be thicke then add of viniger quantum satis and laste add of the powder of bole to colloure it well fiat Emplastum
msItem.note: ff. 81r-85v have been copied by the same hand.

msItem.title: Charm (?)
msItem.note: A partially faded text, largely written in Greek letters, referring to 'parchment' and apparently invoking holy names, ending: 'the power of the almightie and by his unspekable names as you shall answer at the latter day'.

msItem.title: Medical poem
msItem.incipit: 81r Wit from the minde / Speache from the tounge / Frome gale proceadith Ire / From milte is causide laughter / From the lyuer [ludes desier]
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: The first recipe is entitled: ffor the scratches of a horsse foote.

msItem.title: Extracts from A Floorish vpon Fancie (London: Richard Jhones, 1577 and 1582)
msItem.author: Nicholas Breton
msItem.incipit: 86v They liue and lacke, they lack and yet they haue / [And hauing] yet they lacke the thing they craue
msItem.explicit: 86v An answere: [But as I judge] madam quoth I it seames appolloes sicknes sure
msItem.note: The page contains a couplet from Breton’s A dolorous Discourse, of one that was bewitched with love; stanzas from A Letter sent by a Gentlewoman, in verse, to her Husband, being ouer sea, the poem Two or three prety toyes given to a Gentilman, to set about his Counting-house (complete), and stanzas from A pretty toye, written vpon a Ladyes propounding of a Riddle to her friende.

support.material: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 1r-86v: Pot ( 60 20 ) in the centre of the folio, comparable to Heawood 3548 (but in this case inscribed with the initials 'P V') This example is dated to 1570.

extent.seg: Codex, comprising 80 leaves in 8 paper quires, including two torn leaves (ff. 1, 5) and excluding five paper stubs (ff. 2, 3, 4, 25, 78):

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, perhaps by H.L. PinkPink, H. L..
foliation.p: The torn leaf that has been foliated as '5' is actually the fourth leaf in the quire.
ff. [1a], [1b], [24a], and [77a] are paper stubs of missing leaves.
foliation.note: Folio numbers 2, 3, 4, 25, and 78 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library).

list.item: Quire 412-1 or 10+1 (ff. 33r-43v: either a sexternion with the 2nd leaf missing or a quinternion with an additional single leaf after the 10th leaf)
Quire 810-2 or 8-1+1 (ff. 78r-86v: either a quinternion with the 1st and 2nd leaves missing or a quaternion with the first leaf missing and an additional single leaf after the 8th leaf)

collation.formula: 110-3 (2, 3, 5 excised) 212 310-1 (3 excised) 412-1/10+1 (2 excised or 11 added) 512 610 712 810-1/8-1+1 (1 excised, 2 excised or 9 added)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink in the right corner of lower margins both at the end of quires and inside quires

supportDesc.condition: Eight loose quires with conservation binding: ff. 1, 5 are torn leaves; ff. 2, 3, 4, 25, and 78 are paper stubs often with conservation paper attached. Torn corners and inner margins (at the folds) have been repaired with blank conservation paper. Water damage throughout the manuscript, affecting especially outer margins and corners. Possible ink stains in the final quire. The texts on f. 1v and f. 86v have become faded and are now difficult to read.

layout.seg: No ruling. Single columns. 29-36 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: Copied by various hands in Secretary scripts.

decoDesc.decoNote: The manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

binding.p: Until 2022, the manuscript had been bound together with CUL MSS Dd.6.8, Dd.6.10, and Dd.6.11, in a brown half leather binding with paper sides. The manuscript was disbound at the time of photography and cataloguing (2023) but was bound in a conservation binding in 2024.

provenance.p: John Troutbeck, bap. 1612, d. 1683 Troutbeck, John (bap. 1612, d. 1683), physician and chemist: perhaps owned the manuscript and signed his name on f. 55v: 'John Troutbeck' (2x) and 'John Trout'. If so, the 'E.T.' who has marked recipes with their initials throughout the manuscript may be John's father: Edmund Troutbeck, who was known as a surgeon and doctor.

history.acquisition: The manuscript has not been identified in the early catalogues of Cambridge University Library and the date of its accession is not known.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo) , The Index of Middle English Prose, 17 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009)

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo)

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
